G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this personal injury action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this personal injury action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 8 because the events giving rise to the claim occurred at Defendant’s premises in Somerville, Massachusetts.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 706.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners have a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises safe for lawful visitors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 706.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Although the excerpt provided is a concurrence focusing on trespassers, the majority at 363 Mass. 706 explicitly states that an occupier owes a duty to exercise reasonable care for lawful visitors’ safety. Thus, the case is correctly cited for the proposition that Massachusetts property owners must use reasonable care to keep premises safe for lawful visitors.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 706.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. Henceforth, the occupier of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors.” (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973).)

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783–84 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a safe condition and to warn of any unreasonably dangerous conditions of which it was aware or reasonably should have been aware.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recites and applies the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 standard governing a possessor of land’s duty to invitees, which is to exercise reasonable care regarding conditions on the land, including discovering conditions that pose an unreasonable risk and protecting invitees against them. The court then discusses Massachusetts’ traditional rule that a store owner must maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition and may be liable when it has actual or constructive notice of dangerous conditions. This directly supports the stated proposition about a landowner’s duty of reasonable care to invitees to maintain safe premises and warn of unreasonably dangerous conditions it knew or should have known about, even though the case then modifies how notice can be shown via the mode-of-operation doctrine.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: ‘A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition, and should realize that it involves an unreasonable risk of harm to such invitees, … and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.’ Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach… A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition….’”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a safe condition and to warn of any unreasonably dangerous conditions of which it was aware or reasonably should have been aware.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep them reasonably safe for patrons and to warn of dangers not likely to be known to them but known or reasonably knowable to the defendant. That is the same duty described in the proposition, applied here to the MBTA’s subway station and its patrons, who are business invitees. The case thus directly supports the quoted proposition as a statement of Massachusetts premises-liability law for lawful invitees.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: B. Interest on all damages pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
